items.title: CIA conducted first drone strike inside Venezuela

featured_image.name: 'This Is an Act of War': CIA Carried Out Drone Strike on Port ...

items.description:
The CIA carried out a drone strike on a port facility inside Venezuela earlier this month, marking the first confirmed US attack on Venezuelan soil since the Trump administration launched an aggressive military campaign in the Caribbean four months ago[1][2][3].

President Donald Trump publicly acknowledged the strike on December 29, stating there was a "major explosion" in a dock area where boats were allegedly loaded with drugs[1][4][3]. The operation, which CNN first reported, targeted a remote dock on Venezuela's coast that US officials believed was used by the Tren de Aragua gang to store and transport narcotics[1][2][5]. No casualties were reported as the facility was empty at the time of the strike[1][2][6].

Trump initially revealed the attack during a radio interview on December 26, saying the US had destroyed a "big facility where the ships come from" two nights earlier, placing the strike around December 24[7][8]. When pressed by reporters about whether the CIA or military conducted the operation, Trump declined to provide details. "I know exactly who it was, but I don't want to say who it was," he said at his Mar-a-Lago residence[4][9].

items.title: Global markets close 2025 with sharp volatility

featured_image.name: ‘You Had to Be Brave': Wall Street Remembers a Wild 2025

items.description:
Global stock markets closed out 2025 with a year defined by extraordinary volatility and divergent regional performances, as investors navigated policy whiplash from Washington and dramatic swings in commodities and cryptocurrencies.

U.S. markets finished the year near record highs despite violent mid-year turbulence. The S&P 500 gained approximately 17.4% for 2025, while the Nasdaq Composite surged 21%[1][2][3]. However, these gains masked what traders called one of the most volatile years in recent memory, punctuated by President Donald Trump's tariff announcements in April that sent global markets into a tailspin[4][5].

The defining moment came April 2-3, when Trump's "Liberation Day" tariff announcement triggered the worst two-day decline for the S&P 500 since the pandemic began, with the index teetering on the brink of a bear market[4][5]. Markets rebounded dramatically on April 9 when Trump paused many tariffs for 90 days, with the S&P 500 soaring 9.5% in a single session—its largest one-day gain since October 2008[4].

items.title: China condemns record US arms sale as Taiwan drills escalate

featured_image.name: What to know about China's drills around Taiwan as rockets fired on ...

items.description:
China's foreign minister condemned a record US arms sale to Taiwan on Tuesday as Beijing conducted a second day of military exercises encircling the island, firing rockets closer to Taiwan's main landmass than in previous drills.

Foreign Minister Wang Yi said China must "firmly oppose and forcefully counter" the large-scale US arms sales to Taiwan during an annual diplomatic symposium in Beijing[1][2]. His comments marked the most senior Chinese official response to the $11 billion weapons package announced by the US State Department earlier this month[3][4].

items.title: Iran president orders talks with protesters over economic crisis

featured_image.name: Iran's government offers dialogue to protesters

items.description:
Iranian President Masoud Pezeshkian called on his government to address the "legitimate demands" of protesters Tuesday, following two days of demonstrations in Tehran sparked by the national currency's collapse to a historic low and soaring inflation that has pushed the country toward an economic crisis[1][2][3][4].

The rial plunged to 1.42 million against the U.S. dollar on Sunday before recovering slightly to 1.38 million on Monday, according to multiple reports[5][6][7]. The currency has lost more than two-thirds of its value since 2022, when it traded at approximately 430,000 to the dollar[5]. Annual inflation reached 42.2 percent in December, with food prices surging 72 percent year-over-year, according to Iran's Statistical Center[5][8][9].

items.title: Saudi Arabia warns UAE-backed forces are a threat to its national security

featured_image.name: Saudi coalition will counter Yemen separatists undermining de-escalation

items.description:
Saudi Arabia declared a United Arab Emirates-backed separatist advance in Yemen a threat to its national security on Tuesday, marking the strongest public rebuke yet between the Gulf powers as their decade-long alliance in Yemen's civil war fractures over competing strategic interests[1][2].

The warning came hours after a Saudi-led coalition airstrike struck weapons shipments at Yemen's Mukalla port that Riyadh said originated from the UAE, intensifying a confrontation that threatens to reshape the region's power dynamics. Yemen's Saudi-backed Presidential Leadership Council cancelled its defense pact with the UAE and demanded all Emirati forces leave the country within 24 hours[1][3].

"The Kingdom expresses its disappointment by the actions taken by the brotherly United Arab Emirates, pressuring the Southern Transitional Council's forces to conduct military operations on the southern border of the Kingdom," Saudi Arabia's foreign ministry said in a statement[1][2]. The ministry called the UAE's actions "highly dangerous" and warned that any threat to Saudi national security is "a red line"[1][2].

items.title: South Korea's Lee to visit China next week

featured_image.name: Issues at stake in summit between China's Xi and South Korea's Lee

items.description:
South Korean President Lee Jae Myung will travel to China from January 4 to 7 for his first state visit to Beijing since taking office in June, the Blue House announced Tuesday[1][2][3][4]. The trip marks the first visit by a South Korean leader to China in six years and comes as Lee seeks to restore ties strained under his predecessor[1][5].

Lee will meet with Chinese President Xi Jinping in Beijing from January 4 to 6 for a summit and state dinner before traveling to Shanghai, according to presidential spokesperson Kang Yu-jung[3][6]. The visit reciprocates Xi's three-day state visit to South Korea in late October, which was the Chinese leader's first trip to the country in 11 years[1][5][7].

items.title: China orders chipmakers to use 50% domestic equipment

featured_image.name: China mandates 50% domestic equipment rule for chipmakers, sources say

items.description:
China has mandated that semiconductor manufacturers use at least 50 percent domestically produced equipment when expanding production capacity, according to three people familiar with the matter, marking one of Beijing's most significant measures to reduce dependence on foreign technology[1][2][3].

The unpublicized rule, communicated to chipmakers by government officials in recent months, requires companies seeking state approval for new or expanded facilities to demonstrate through procurement tenders that at least half their equipment will be Chinese-made[1][2][4]. Applications that fail to meet this threshold are typically rejected, though authorities grant flexibility depending on supply constraints[1][2].

items.title: US grants Samsung, SK Hynix annual chip export licenses

featured_image.name: Samsung King's Cross Brand Showcase At Coal Drops Yard In London

items.description:
The US government has granted annual licenses to Samsung Electronics and SK Hynix allowing them to ship chipmaking equipment to their Chinese factories in 2026, according to sources familiar with the matter on Tuesday[1][2][3]. The approval offers temporary relief to the South Korean memory chip manufacturers as they navigate tightening US export controls on semiconductor technology to China.

The licenses replace a fast-track export privilege known as "validated end user" status that expires December 31, 2025[1][2][3]. Under the new system, the companies must seek approval annually for restricted equipment, parts, and materials in specific quantities[4][5], marking a shift from the indefinite authorizations they previously enjoyed under the Biden administration.

items.title: 2025 among three hottest years despite no El Niño

featured_image.name: The year in rainforests 2025: Deforestation fell; the risks did not

items.description:
Multiple urgent warnings from climate researchers have emerged in the final days of 2025, highlighting the accelerating pace of environmental crises driven by human activity, from invasive species wreaking havoc on agricultural systems to unprecedented sea level acceleration and potential ocean circulation collapse.

The World Weather Attribution released its annual report on December 29, showing that 2025 was one of the three hottest years on record despite the absence of El Niño warming conditions[1][2]. According to researchers, extreme weather events intensified across all continents, with heatwaves becoming up to 10 times more likely than a decade ago due to climate change[3][2]. The report documented 157 severe extreme weather events that met criteria including more than 100 deaths or displacement of thousands[3].

items.title: 2025 ties for second-hottest year as extreme weather kills thousands

featured_image.name: European heatwave caused 2,300 deaths, scientists estimate

items.description:
Scientists confirmed Tuesday that 2025 ranks as one of the three hottest years on record, with human-caused climate change driving deadly extreme weather events across the globe that killed thousands and displaced millions. The year's global average temperature reached 1.48°C above pre-industrial levels—marking the first time a three-year average has exceeded the critical 1.5°C threshold set by the 2015 Paris Agreement[1][2][3].

The findings from World Weather Attribution researchers show that 2025 will tie with 2023 as the second-hottest year, trailing only 2024[4][5]. Temperatures remained exceptionally high despite La Niña conditions—a natural cooling pattern—underscoring the dominant role of fossil fuel emissions in warming the planet[4][6].

items.title: Taiwan's Lai vows no escalation as China drills enter second day

featured_image.name: Taiwan president rallies the troops ahead of possible Chinese drills

items.description:
Taiwan President Lai Ching-te pledged Tuesday that his government would "act responsibly, without escalating the conflict or provoking disputes" as China conducted a second day of major military drills around the self-ruled island[1][2]. The statement came as Beijing deployed what Taiwan's defense ministry described as 14 naval ships, 89 military aircraft, and an amphibious strike force in exercises designed to simulate a blockade[3].

"The Chinese Communist Party's escalation of military pressure is not the conduct expected from a responsible power," Lai said in a social media statement Tuesday morning, adding that Taiwan's military and national security team would "do their utmost to ensure the safety of the nation"[4]. Presidential Office spokesperson Karen Kuo condemned China's actions as "military intimidation" that "undermine the stability and security of the Taiwan Strait and Indo-Pacific region"[5][6][7].

items.title: Earth exceeds Paris Agreement warming limit for first time

featured_image.name: 2025 will be world's second or third-hottest year on record, EU scientists say

items.description:
For the first time since nations pledged to limit global warming, the three-year average temperature has exceeded the 1.5°C threshold set by the 2015 Paris Agreement, scientists reported in a study released Sunday. The period spanning 2023 to 2025 marks a critical milestone in the acceleration of climate change, with 2025 ranking as one of the three hottest years on record[1][2][3][4].

The findings from researchers at World Weather Attribution, published December 29, underscore how human-induced climate change made 2025 one of the warmest years ever documented, despite the presence of La Niña conditions that typically cool global temperatures[1][5]. The European Union's Copernicus Climate Change Service reported that November 2025 saw global temperatures reach 1.54°C above pre-industrial levels[3][4].

"If we do not cease the burning of fossil fuels very quickly, it will become exceedingly difficult to achieve that warming goal," said Friederike Otto, co-lead of World Weather Attribution and a climate scientist at Imperial College London[1]. "The scientific evidence is becoming increasingly unequivocal."
